19.21.text:
Science is often thought of as simply a collection
of facts that has been handed down by some

24.66.text:
great authority in the past, but of course
the reality is much more complicated than

28.59.text:
that. The facts that we know today about science,
were only arrived at after a great deal of

33.82.text:
research…debate – in fact, some of the
greatest scientists in history have been spectacularly

40.20.text:
wrong in the past. So what all of this means
is that: one thing that is never very far away from science is controversy.

51.66.text:
I work in climate science and one of the things I work on is atmospheric turbulence. The fact
that the climate can change was once very

57.81.text:
controversial among the scientific community,
and of course it still is controversial today…not

62.70.text:
among the science community any more, but
amongst the general public. I’m interested

69.29.text:
in tracking the history of controversy in
science, so I’m travelling north to meet

73.49.text:
Geoffrey Boulton, who is a Fellow of the Royal
Society, and he is noted for the work he’s

78.34.text:
done that shows that the climate has changed
very dramatically, quite recently in geological terms.

86.18.text: "So where exactly are we heading Geoffrey?"

90.38.text:
"Well, we’ve just come out of the lowlands
and shortly we’ll be turning off to the

94.28.text:
Wet, to the area around Ben Nevis, and in
particular to Glen Roy, where there are quite

99.32.text:
extraordinary features on the hillsides, which
are quite unique in Britain, and illustrate

104.31.text:
a quite extraordinary controversy of about
200 years ago, which is the beginning of the

108.63.text:
modern view of the way in which the climate
works and how it evolves over time."

111.87.text:
"Well, I can’t wait to see them."
"Let’s hope my safe driving will conduct you there!"

124.90.text: "Wow! So these are the parallel roads of Glen Roy."

132.19.text:
These horizontal lines along the hillside.
There are three of them, and they all maintain

137.80.text:
pretty much the same altitude through this
valley – Glen Roy – and Glen Gloy to the

142.88.text:
west, and they puzzled people for many years.
Charles Darwin came here in 1838, fresh from

149.34.text:
his voyage on the Beagle to South America,
where he was sure he’d seen similar features,

153.93.text:
along the hillsides, which had shale sands
on them, and which he – I think, correctly

158.68.text:
– interpreted as having been beaches that
had lain at sea level. He came here and he

162.96.text:
was convinced he was seeing the same thing
– and indeed he published a paper in the

166.74.text:
Royal Society’s Philosophical Transactions
saying exactly that in 1839."

171.89.text:
"So the big question is: was he right?"
"I’m afraid he wasn’t. It seems like a

177.43.text:
hard thing to say about Charles Darwin, but
I’m afraid he got it wrong. There were two

180.64.text:
problems however: one of them was that he
didn’t see any sea shells here, which is

184.06.text:
what he’d expected; the other is something
you can see if we look at this map. This shows

189.33.text:
the distribution of these parallel roads – what
you see is that the roads marked by these

195.10.text:
red lines occur in Glen Roy and in Glen Gloy,
but nowhere else... and Darwin couldn’t

202.17.text:
explain why there weren’t more widespread,
for if the whole of Western Scotland had been

206.21.text:
uplifted by tectonic forces that’s what
he would have expected. The solution came

212.51.text:
three or four years later when the young Swiss
Geologist Louis Agassiz came here – he saw

216.82.text:
these features and thought immediately he
knew how they’d formed, in a way that explained

221.74.text:
why they occurred in these valleys but not
in adjacent valleys nor in any other part

226.23.text:
of the western Highlands. He saw, close by
here, bedrock surfaces which had typical grooves

233.00.text:
ground on them by glaciers. What he did, which
is what I’ve done, is to draw this blue

237.75.text:
line on the map where the terminus of a glacier
lay, that dammed up these lakes and valleys

243.05.text:
– the water draining over the cols at their
heads, and the elevation of the cols determining

249.54.text:
how high the individual roads were."
"So if we were standing here – what, 12,000

256.08.text:
years ago – we’d be standing at the bottom
of a lake, right?"

259.84.text: "We would. We’d have been blowing bubbles, and we’d have been beneath about 150 metres of water."

263.84.text: "So, shall we find somewhere to warm up?"

274.88.text:
"Well, I think what we saw today was a splendid example of how progress is made in science,
with the introduction of new ideas, new evidence,

282.61.text:
dramatically changing our scientific understanding
of the facts, obliterating an old theory and

288.15.text:
allowing a new theory to come in and take
its place."

290.76.text:
"It’s important to recognise as well that
Darwin, who later became a great scientific

294.87.text:
icon, could make serious errors as he did
in Glen Roy. This is the Philosophical Transactions

300.49.text:
from 1839 with Darwin’s paper in it. If
you look at Darwin’s map, then the location

307.36.text:
and elevation of the roads is pretty much
exactly what you would find in a modern map

311.17.text:
using satellite imagery…so Darwin’s facts
have remained steady, and constant, and usable,

317.29.text:
but of course his theory is now we know completely
wrong. Darwin himself, of course, recognised

323.62.text:
this, and in – I’ve got a copy here of
his book, ‘On the Descent of Man’ – he

329.07.text:
writes: “false facts are highly injurious
to the progress of science, for they often

333.47.text:
endure long…but false views do little harm,
for everyone takes a great pleasure if proving

339.22.text:
their falseness.”"
"That’s a great quotation – and of course

342.33.text:
scientific publishing played a critical role
in the resolution of this particular controversy.

348.76.text:
Before the launch of Philosophical Transactions
in 1665, scientific ideas were not accessible

355.68.text:
to the public; they were not published – they
were confined to the private letters of the

360.71.text:
scientists. So the advent of scientific publishing
was a means to formalise scientific controversy."

367.04.text:
"It stimulated tremendous debate, but not only
from the scientific community itself, but

371.11.text:
actually from the broader public. Edmond Halley
in the early years of the 18th century estimated

377.15.text:
the age of the Earth to be far, far greater
than the age deduced from the Biblical record,

383.09.text:
and of course in the public domain, he was
strongly criticised for having the boldness

387.32.text:
to publish this openly in the Philosophical
Transactions, but it’s crucial really for

392.11.text:
the progress of science and human understanding
that we are prepared to produce bold new ideas

398.73.text:
based on evidence rather than simply accepting
some external authority."

402.86.text:
"That brings us nicely to the present day,
and contemporary climate change. Scientists

407.37.text:
have overwhelming evidence that the climate
has changed over the past century or so, and

413.23.text:
that the cause of that change is not natural
variability, which is associated with the

418.35.text:
origin of the parallel roads, but human influence,
and we have what has been referred to as a

423.88.text:
consensus gap, between what we have in the
scientific community, which is overwhelming

428.98.text:
levels of agreement, and what exists in some
parts of the public sphere – a perception

435.11.text:
that that level of agreement is absent."
"And notwithstanding controversies like that,

439.88.text:
I mean the crucial thing is that science has
to be an open, public enterprise, rather than

446.39.text:
one that is behind closed laboratory doors,
and the challenge for the future is, we’ve

450.67.text:
got to keep it that way."
"Well, I’ll certainly drink to that. Cheers!"
